Key Match Events: Houston erupted for nearly 70 points in the first half, shooting 56% from the floor (28-50) and 38% from downtown (8-21).
Jalen Green added 18 points in the first quarter alone, finishing the contest with 33 with five triples.
Anthony Davis led the team with 30 points, 13 rebounds, and five blocks.
Max Christie took the ball out past half court. Every Laker was smothered by the Houston defense, leading Christie to force a bad pass to James that was intercepted by Fred VanVleet.
Dorian Finney-Smith found a wide-open James at the top of the key who buried the deep triple. However, the shot was waved off as Davis was called for an offensive foul.
Pre-Game Insights: Since LeBron James’s return, the squad boasted the seventh-best offense and 10th-best defense in the NBA.
They won seven of nine contests, catapulting to a top seed in the Western Conference.
Post-Match Reflections: James – who finished the game with 21 points, 13 rebounds, and nine assists – explained to reporters that he signaled for a timeout before Christie had inbounded the ball.
Davis vehemently disagreed with the referee’s late whistle.
Our inability to get defensive rebounds was the difference in the game, said coach Redick in his postgame interview.

The Rockets are the best rebounding team in the league and the Lakers are one of the worst. And when it came to cleaning glass on Sunday night, Houston was a bottle of Windex while Los Angeles was a packet of ketchup.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Rockets grabbed a whopping 18 offensive boards that resulted in 28 second-chance points, which continuously halted the Lakers’ momentum.
Anthony Davis recorded a career-high 16 rebounds to go along with 23 points.
With the loss, the Lakers dropped to 20-15 and fell to fifth place in the Western Conference.
